title: Wales Was Only Choice For Me, Says Bale
text:
Wales Was Only Choice For Me, Says Bale 10:59, UK, Thursday 15 October 2015 Share by email Gareth Bale has said he was never in any doubt about representing Wales - even though he had the chance of playing international football for England. 
The Real Madrid forward helped the Welsh to their first major tournament appearance since 1956 last week, Chris Coleman's side finishing second in their European Qualifying group for next summer's competition in France. 
Despite being eligible to play for England through his grandmother, Bale has 54 caps for Wales, and says he doesn't regret his decision. 
Bale, who made his debut for Wales in 2006 and was on target in Tuesday's 2-0 win over Andorra at a rocking Cardiff City Stadium, said: "It was never an option. I was really young at the time. It was literally a one-second conversation. 
"I said 'Stop, I'm from Wales and love Wales'. Everyone knows how much I love playing for Wales. 
"My grandmother's English, but I'm Welsh and I would never want it to happen." 
Bale scored seven goals in Wales' 10 group games, including vital winners against Andorra, Belgium and Cyprus, and the 26-year-old praised the support Coleman's side gained from the whole country over the qualification period. 
"The passion from our players is I would say the best in the world. You never see a nation get behind the team like Wales, whether it's away from home or at home, or whether it's for the football or for the rugby. 
"The anthem is just incredible when it's sung, even in the middle of a game. Everyone pulls together in one direction." Promoted Stories
